p: Saponins (triterpenoid saponin, tea saponin, methanol extract saponin) are the potential additives which cause a significant reduction of protozoa population in the rumen, as a result, methane production is reduced [ 140â€“ 142]. Saponins also contribute rumen fermentation, enhance rumen bacterial populations, and ruminant productivity [ 50, 136, 137]. Saponins from different sources show various results. Application of Quillaja saponin at 1.2 g/L decreased CH 4 production in-vitro, but not at 0.6 g/L [ 143]. The ivy fruit saponin decreased CH4 production by 40% [ 144] and saponins from Saponaria officinalis reduced CH 4 and abundance of both methanogens and protozoa in-vitro [ 145]. However, the opposite result was found in other in-vitro studies, where Quillaja saponins at 0.6 g/L did not reduce CH 4 production or abundance of methanogen [ 146, 147]. Similarly, Tea saponins (30 g/day) also did not reduce CH 4 emission from steers or methanogens abundance [ 148]. Though, the effects of saponins on methanogenesis and methanogen abundance are greatly inconstant among different studies, still needed to study more.
